title: list of typophile designers
content: Is there a list anywhere on this site (typowiki?) of which active typophiles are also type designers - and their web sites? It would be good to know both as a reference point and in order to patronize their sites and buy their fonts.
author: pattyfab

the hard thing is who do we include/exclude? Do we just include regulars like Mark, or do we include everyone who's ever posted even if only once or twice? do we only list prolific type designers (like i did above) or do we include the dabblers?

Yeah, that's a good question. I'd probably restrict it to people who have fonts licensed and for sale either at their own sites or at Fontshop, Myfonts, Veer, etc.

Maybe we start with the typophile regulars.
But shouldn't we be advertising?

\> I’ve also seen Magnus Rakeng here ...

Then there's the Lurking Army of the Busy & Famous.

\> who do we include/exclude?

Are there enough of us to exclude anybody? If you must, I guess you could only include people who have ever been on the prolific posters list (which you could hopefully automate). Or you could restrict it to paying members, to motivate membership\*. As for exclusions on the type design end, that's certainly a can of worms...

\* How's that going, btw? :-)

\> But shouldn’t we be advertising?

You mean formally? :-\>

hhp

Anyway, if it's a fully open wiki, forget about exclusions,  
all you can do is edit for formal accuracy. Like when one

so any living designer who has ever posted on typophile is our criteria? i don't think that anyone necessarily needs to be excluded, but for this list to be helpful, it should have some qualifications. No?

_You mean formally?_

Right, paying cash money for a banner ad.  
But it's not a very effective medium for font sales.

\> qualifications

Paul, what about:  
1) Has sold a font.  
2) Has been on the prolific posters list and/or is a member.  
3) Is alive.

Although I do see some room to move on #2.

hhp

I originated this post following a very nice email exchange with Stefan Hattenbach during which I realized I had no idea he had designed some beautiful fonts. I guess my motivation was for my own information - to know who among the people who frequent this site are actually type designers and what they've done. I'm a graphic designer and do buy fonts for jobs and would like to patronize Typophiles when appropriate. This is a 'community' after all, and reading another thread ( [http://typophile.com/node/19846](http://web.archive.org/web/20120129114804/http:/typophile.com/node/19846 "http://typophile.com/node/19846")) in which Rory expresses frustration trying to communicate with foundries it occurred to me he might find a more supportive group here - and perhaps end up buying a font.

It also gives some perspective on their contributions to the threads. I think the wiki when complete might stimulate some sales - at least from me.

But that said, I don't think the criteria need to be too rigid. Let's hope nobody dies any time soon...
I don't think #2 is necessary. For instance. I don't think Mr. Berlow has been on that list yet, but he certainly has contributed in a very valuable way.

Well, I think #2 needs help, but something does need to be there.  
And really, the problem with the prolific posters list is that it's based  
on number of posts, not number of bytes (with <cite>quality</cite> of posts being  
sadly too utopian a potential measure).

What if we made the "participation" benchmark having started a thread?  
For one thing it's easy to check: you go the tracker in the profile, and check  
for his name in the Author column.

hhp
I'd say if we limit it to members at least that they don't have to be prolific posters, especially since that only seems to track the last 10 days.
I have seen Peter Bruhn of Fountain logged in, but not sure if he participates. Graham Meade of Typotheticals is sometimes here, although until he starts charging more he will probably have a stigma.

Eric Spiekerman and Christian Schwartz certainly qualify as well as Hoefler.
